events.text: I had to make my exit. But first, the formal goodbyes.
Can't say I did. Groundskeeper said he gave Thoroughbred a meal ration with a tray, but there's no tray up in the office.
Mmm, no, I don't think so.
Stainless steel. Sturdy, thin, meant to be re-used.
Hmm... fits the murder weapon profile, for sure. But you didn't see it up there?
A stainless steel lie nestled against my chest, underneath my coat.
I couldn't give her the criminal. But I could toss her a scrap or two of info, let her feel she was making progress.

It adds up though. Food spatter mixed with the blood, probably leftovers still on the tray. You can get coroner to compare size of the wound with some trays from the groundskeeper, see if it lines up.
What doesn't make sense to me is Thoroughbred is a notorious gun nut. Anybody planning to kill him could have used one of his weapons. Or their own. A knife. Not a damn dinner tray.
I think you said it best earlier. Crime of passion doesn't need a reason.

She kept talking out loud, and I gave her non-answers and head nods. Let her do some deductions. She had no reason to suspect me, not without the actual weapon and fingerprints. I'd given her enough to chew on. As long as I hadn't left any traces, there was nothing pinned to me.
My heart pounded against my chest like an inmate screaming innocence from a cell. I might just get away with it after all.
After a little while, she lapsed into thoughtful silence.
